title: Any Serious Alternative to FF Kievit?
content:
Does anybody know a serious alternative to the typeface [FF Kievit](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414232925/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/fontfont/ff_kievit_pro_book/?&sample_text=Perceptual%20Experience%20%26%20Knowledge&sample_size=24&update=0)? A double storey g is at least desired.

Thanks!
author: deadman

comments.content: [Flex](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414232925/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/bold_monday/flex_ot/) comes to mind. It’s from Paul van der Laan who helped with Kievit. Can you talk about the reasons why FF Kievit won't work for you?

[Hubert Jocham](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414232925/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Hubert%20Jocham)’s [Safran](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414232925/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/hubertjocham/safran/?refby=mfde) is another, slightly more broad-pen-flavoured option. The family spans 9 weights, and also the italics have a double-storey ‘g’. There’s a [Pro version](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414232925/http:/www.hubertjocham.de/item.php/type/sans/SafranPro/) with small caps and extended language support.  
But Stephen’s right: without knowing why FF Kievit is out of the question, it’s impossible to come up with suitable alternatives for you.

Thank you, Stephen. Thank you, Florian.

I don’t really know wether or not Kievit will work. I guess it will. I’m looking for a sans serif (with no or at least modest modulation) that is neutral and clear. It has to serve two purposes: (a and most of all) to work well as a headline typeface together with FF Scala (, Minion and Albertina) as body text typeface; (b) to work as a body text typeface as well (good legibility).

I’m just a non-professional, and I’m just interested in typography for my own purposes (typesetting scientific texts). Hence, I like to be sure, that I’ve chosen the ›right‹ font, before I purchase a license.

You do know that FF Scala is a [superfamily](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414232925/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/super_families/ff_scala/) that includes a perfectly matching [Scala Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414232925/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_scala_sans_ot/)?
Yes, I know. But Scala Sans—a wonderful typeface—reveals in my opinion too much character in taller sizes, at least for my purposes.
